ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL ESTATES
(Upgrading)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Heng Chiang Meng -

    1. To ask the Minister for National Development when the programme for the upgrading of private residential estates will be implemented and what form such a programme will take.

    Mr Bernard Chen (West Coast): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed scheme to improve private residential estates aims to improve the physical environment of

Column: 1413

these estates. Items being considered for improvement include landscaping, play equipment, park furniture and the widening of footpaths. This will be over and above the on-going maintenance works provided by the various Government agencies.

    The Government had earlier deferred the implementation of the scheme due to the economic downturn. Since the economy has recovered, we will proceed to reactivate the scheme. The Ministry of National Development is currently in the process of working out the implementation details of the scheme. The Committee is looking into the possibility of starting one or two pilot projects in the second half of this year. This will enable the Committee to learn the best way to improve the physical environment of the private residential estates. Selection criteria will include the physical condition of the estate, and the level of community bonding and support among the residents in the estate.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, in the selection of the private estates, can I volunteer some of the private estates in my constituency because I had actually proposed this idea some years ago and it had not been taken up? There are quite a number of estates which are quite well organised, in terms of neighbourliness, and also conducive for this purpose.

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will take up his suggestion.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, can I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether private estates also include private condominiums?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: We are looking into this suggestion. We are thinking of providing this improvement project item to the area outside the condominium. In other words, we will only put in improvement works on state land, not inside the condominium.

Column: 1414



    Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, like the HDB Interim Upgrading programme where $4,000 per unit is allocated, would private residents have a similar budget? And can it go beyond the MND budget where they have got National Parks Board and other statutory boards, like ENV, drains, and so on, and where they can pool together the budget for this upgrading to reach $4,000 per unit figure?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, that is indeed the idea. I said in my answer that the funding will be provided over and above the on-going maintenance works provided by the various Government agencies, like LTA, National Parks, Environment.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, my question relates to funding as well. What is the total budget his Ministry will be allocating for these two pilot projects, or other projects related to the improvement of private estates?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are still trying to work out the budget with the Ministry of Finance.

    Mr Sinnakaruppan: I think he has not answered my question. When he says more than the present amount, would it be near the $4,000 benchmark?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: As I said in my reply to Dr Wang, we are looking into the final details of the budget.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Given that the scope of works contemplated is relatively modest, can we envisage an early start date for the project and faster implementation because we are only talking about things like landscaping and footpath widening? I do not see this as being terribly complicated.

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: We will try to start one or two by the second half of this year. We are already in March. So the second half can be a few months away.

Column: 1415



    Mr Simon S C Tay (Nominated Member): The Senior Parliamentary Secretary has said that, for condominiums, they will probably do it on public land. May I take it that it is a principle of private estate upgrading that no private land will be taken?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Yes.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, could I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary this question? He talks about one of the factors being community bonding. Will it be possible for communities that are found to be quite well bonded to be helped along with the provision of facilities like the RC centre or clubhouse?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: That depends on the number of houses or condominium units in that precinct. The funding will be based on X dollars per household within that precinct. So if there is enough money to do something big, I think we can consider. But bear in mind that private estates are not like HDB estates. The total number of household size will be small. So we do not envisage a big project to be in place.

    Mr Iswaran: May I urge the Senior Parliamentary Secretary, in contemplating what projects to implement, will high priority be given to the public transportation access elements, including covered linkways? I know he mentioned that LTA will be involved. But I think that would probably redeem all significant value added to private estate residents rather than parks and footpaths.

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: I think that suggestion would be taken up.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat: Sir, I go back to my earlier question to the Senior Parliamentary Secretary. Like in my constituency, which is actually older than I am, the housing estate has got old schools that are abandoned, or about to be abandoned, and some of these facilities are too small for any other public use, except perhaps a little clubhouse for the residents. I am just thinking that perhaps

Column: 1416

the Ministry could look into funding, renovation, and the TOL that we have to pay to the Land Office.

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Member to write to me and give me the details of his proposal?

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary what happens if the improvement work is on HDB land because many of the condominiums or private estates are adjoining the HDB estate? Therefore, the improvement work has to be done on HDB land. Under the traditional CIPC grant, if the improvement works are on HDB land, then this grant cannot be used. Could he clarify this matter?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: I think the policy is very clear. If the estate sits on HDB land, in other words, we call it the common area, then we will use CIPC funding. If it sits on private land, then we can consider using the Committee for Improvements to Private Residential Estate (CIPRE) fund.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: I am pointing out this particular issue because one of the condominium developments would like to build one of the covered linkways. But the linkway is actually on HDB land. In this case, it will be under HDB's CIPC fund, and not under other community improvement funds. Actually, the linkway is only used for the private estate. Could the Senior Parliamentary Secretary clarify whether or not that can be done?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: If the linkway sits on HDB land, then CIPC fund will have to be sought. If the linkway crosses from the HDB land to the private estate land, then you will have to apply for money under the CIPRE fund, and the coordination must be done between the MC and the Town Council.

    Mr Simon Tay: Mr Speaker, may I look forward to the day of maintenance. May I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether the private estate improvements will be maintained and funded from the

Column: 1417

general coffers of Government or will there be any special arrangements?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: The funding will come from the Ministry of Finance. So this is Government's money.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang: Can we start with more private projects, instead of just two, because I remember we started off with four MUP projects?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: MUP is quite different. HDB has been in the public housing business for 40 years. So they know what they are doing. In this case, we are entering into a new business and we will tread very carefully. So we will start with one or two projects by the end of this year. We will learn from these two projects and we can speed up the number of projects next year, if necessary.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng (Bukit Gombak): Mr Speaker, Sir, will this project apply to all the new and old housing estates?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: In theory, yes. But, in practice, we would like to apply this fund to the old estates first.

    Mr Ang Mong Seng: How old is an old estate?

    Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee: We have to look at each estate separately because some old estates have just been upgraded by the National Parks Board and Environment. Some new estates may not have been upgraded yet. The cut-off line is quite blur, unlike HDB estates.

    The Chairman: Main and Development Estimates of Expenditure of Singapore for the financial year, 1st April, 2000 to 31st March, 2001 contained in Paper Cmd No. 2 of 2000.

    For convenience, I shall take the totals for each head of expenditure in the Main and Development Estimates as they appear in the last columns of the schedules of estimated expenditure under the Main and Development Estimates Outlays for FY 2000/2001 on pages 37 and 38 respectively of the Command Paper.

    Besides the "guillotine" times for heads of expenditure, which I have fixed under Standing Order 89(7)(a), I have also allotted the time for discussion of each amendment in the Estimates. The time allotted for discussion includes the replies from the front bench. I shall announce these times as we go along.

    Members have submitted a record number of 529 notices of amendments. Perhaps, Members have decided to subject me to a more vigorous test of my patience this year. But indeed, it shows the seriousness in which we, as legislators, treat this annual debate on the budgets for the different Ministries. However, time is a constraining factor, and Members will therefore not necessarily be given the amount of time they have requested. Members are cognizant of the fact that the time allotted for the debate is not enough, and have readily agreed a while ago to extend the daily sitting hours to 7.00 pm and to an additional sitting day this Saturday till 5.00 pm.

    Nevertheless, we will still be hard-pressed for time and I once again urge Members to keep their speeches to the point so that we can conduct our business at an efficient pace. If not, I must warn Members they risk being "guillotined".

    Members who have not submitted cuts but would like to join in the debate on a particular amendment will be allowed to do so only if there is sufficient time left on the amendment.

Column: 1421



    I shall deal first with the heads of expenditure in respect of which amendments stand on the Order Paper Supplement.

Column: 1421



    Head V -

    The Chairman: Head V - Prime Minister's Office. Amendment No. (1), Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head V of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, in moving this cut, I would like to highlight a difference in motivating staff between the public and the private sectors. The private sector is driven by the bottomline, be it profit and loss or value-added. This philosophy is usually embraced by the entire organisation, literally through thick and thin, through mergers and acquisitions or through industry restructuring.

    Consistent with this, performance targets are in place for the majority of private enterprises. Employees contribute accordingly and generally cannot but feel the pulse of the underlying industry. This is most evident during the recession and the restructuring of the electronics sector. Retrenchment, as we all know, was a painful experience for those affected. The reality was that the profitability of their companies had a direct impact on them.

    By the same token and to complement a fast changing and technology-driven economy, the public sector will increasingly be expected to deliver acceptable value-added. This is particularly so as technology will force more transparency on the entire supply chain, including the delivery of public services.

    Thus, every public sector employee will soon be forced to focus on customer satisfaction at each level, and to be more innovative and entrepreneurial in his approach.

    Sir, our limited manpower resources would be another reason for narrowing

Column: 1422

any disparity in the terms of employment between the public and private sectors. If nothing else, a disparity makes for difficult deployment of capable civil servants to for-profit Government-linked companies or even the private sector.

    It is perhaps inevitable that a performance-based variable may eventually dominate the overall compensation of a typical worker in Singapore. In the private sector, this already takes the form of actual bonuses paid out or stock options. An appropriate equivalent would have to be worked out for civil servants in the long run and, in fact, for all public sector employees. Otherwise, the call for them to be more entrepreneurial would ring hollow.

    I would therefore like to ask the Prime Minister on how the vision of a more entrepreneurial public sector will be realised.

    Mr Simon Tay: Sir, I wish to speak on the need to integrate communication and response to the public as part of the assessment of civil servants, especially among its elite. In this sense, my remarks follow on what the MP for Marine Parade GRC has spoken.

    Sir, Singaporeans have come to expect greater consultation and participation in public life. In the 1980s, the then Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong, made greater consultation one of the central aspects of the second generation government. Institutions for feedback were created, consultation increased, town councils were used to devolve more authority and participation to the local level.

    In the decade since Prime Minister Goh has come into office, further steps have been taken. CDCs now try to bring Government even closer to the people. The Singapore 21 initiative set up by Prime Minister Goh aims for the ideal of "active citizens". This vision is not of a strong people and a weak Government. Nor is it a vision of people opposing Government. Singapore 21 envisions the ideal of a society which people and Government work together, and both are strong.

Column: 1423



    When future generations look back on these 10 years, history may well judge that greater consultation and greater participation are part of the legacy left by Prime Minister Goh and his team.

    On the other hand, Sir, there are some who believe that what we have experienced is more of a function of the present Prime Minister's personal style. Some may point out that Singapore 21 is not explicitly the vision of a third generation of leaders. Many hope that they will come to embrace this vision, but there is no guarantee at present, and this is why I turn to the question of the civil service and institutionalising their ability and willingness to communicate and respond to the public.

    There was a recent debate in the public press which I shall not touch on. However, it is clear that the questions raised were not simply about the National Library or the Bras Basah Park, but broader issues, such as whether there should be benchmarks for the civil service in dealing with public consultation or whether the examples touched upon in this debate can and should be improved in the future.

    Sir, I personally remain optimistic. Promises made are genuinely meant and the change and improvements will come. But I would urge the processes that promote change should be institutionalised. They should be made part of a permanent way of how we do things and how we assess the performance of our civil servants. One very important step in this direction would be to integrate this aspect of communication and response to the public in the assessment of civil servants, especially the elite.

    If we do this, we are setting the right signal that consultation is vital. By including communication and response to the public, we will be moving beyond exhortation. The process of consultation will increasingly be part of the criteria for success. It will no longer be sufficient to ask, "Is the job done, and how well?" It will also be asked, "How was it done?"

    Of course, not all decisions can be consulted. Some are market sensitive.

Column: 1424

Others may touch on security secrets. Exceptions can be justified. Nor of course does consultation mean that public suggestions will always be adopted. In this regard, we must accept that consultation is a complex quality to measure. But the effort must be made.

    A partial analogy can be drawn to the efforts already undertaken by the Government in improving service quality. This has focused on over-the-counter services such as reducing queues in various departments. Such services are important, and improvements are relatively easy to measure. While consultation engagements are more complex to measure, they are no less important qualities. In fact, I believe that they will be increasingly demanded by an increasingly educated and cosmopolitan Singapore.

    Because public consultation is more complex, and because it would be increasingly demanded, the process should therefore begin now. Let greater public consultation and participation go from a promise to a basic premise of Government in Singapore. Let public consultation and participation be institutionalised for the future. I hope in this way, the present Government will lay a foundation stone upon which succeeding governments and generations of citizens can build their home.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Cheng San): Sir, for the past decade, companies in the United States have been continually restructuring their operations to make themselves leaner and more profitable. Now other countries, including Japan, are doing the same things. In Singapore, we have seen companies restructuring not because of economic difficulties, but to become more competitive.

    Globalisation and the rapid change in technology are altering the way companies operate and the way we work. Are we ready for such drastic changes to our working life? We could try to dig in our heels in an attempt to stop these changes. But this would not serve any good. If we insist to resist change, we will do ourselves more harm than good. Instead,

Column: 1425

we need to react fast and prepare our workers early to face the challenge.

    Work has to be redesigned to successfully meet the new demands of the knowledge-based economy and sustain competitiveness. For example, companies have to redesign their work process to be more responsive to customers. Staff have to be empowered with more knowledge and technology to create more value.

    While work redesign is not a new concept, it has taken on a new dimension brought about by our ageing society and higher retirement age. Presently, retirement age is set at 62 but, in due course, it will be raised to 67.

    Besides creating greater efficiency in work processes, work redesign can help workers stay employable for life, through customising work processes for this specific purpose. Work redesign will also remove the stigma attached to some low-level jobs. Moreover, the higher the productivity gain, the better chances there are of our workers to receive better earnings and able to enhance their quality of life.

    The public sector should also consider ways to streamline different schemes of service, better deploy staff, and respond to the higher expectations of a more educated workforce and sustain high productivity gain.

    Now let me cite the example of PSB. From 1996, clerical officers were transformed into administrative executives. With 80% of school leavers going for higher education, PSB found it difficult to recruit clerical grades.

    I also informed Parliament then that the Minister for Finance Dr Hu had written to his Malaysian counterpart, Tun Daim Zainuddin on 13th January 2000. Tun Daim replied on 17th January 2000, and after a further exchange of letters, the KLSE met SGX to discuss a mutually acceptable resolution to the CLOB issue.

    The ensuing negotiations were fruitful and resulted in the SGX-KLSE agreement on 25th February 2000. The agreement is legally binding and provides two schemes for the migration and staggered release of CLOB securities into individual investors' securities accounts. The two exchanges undertake to implement the migration of CLOB securities for trading on the KLSE under these schemes, fully and unconditionally.

    SGX and KLSE have jointly presented the two schemes of their agreement as a comprehensive solution to the CLOB issue. This is a major and timely development after the 17-month impasse in September 1998, during which some 1.5 billion CLOB shares owned by more than 172,000 investors of different nationalities were frozen at the Malaysian Central Depository (MCD).

    In negotiating the agreement, the SGX insisted that it met SGX's and also CLOB investors' key concerns. In particular, both alternatives have to be legally binding on the relevant Malaysian authorities, which should acknowledge their legal obligations to carry out any agreement. In addition, the solution had to be comprehensive, with a reasonable alternative for CLOB investors who did not wish to accept the private sector offer.

    These two key points - firstly, it has to be legally binding. secondly, it has to be comprehensive - which the Malaysian authorities had consistently refused to agree to, are now embodied in the SGX-KLSE agreement. The agreement also confirms that the two migration schemes allow KLSE to meet its duty to maintain an orderly market for the trading of securities in Malaysia.

    The first scheme, Scheme A, is an amended proposal by Effective Capital

    Investors who opt for this scheme will pay ECSB a 1.5% transfer fee based on the closing prices in the KLSE on 15th February this year. There will be a three-month set-up period (for the opening of individual securities accounts with MCD) commencing from 31st March 2000, followed by a 13-month staggered release of the CLOB securities for trading on the KLSE.

    Scheme B, the second scheme, is effected by a supplemental agreement between CDP and SCANS. Investors will have their securities migrated into individual accounts and released for trading on the KLSE after 33 months from 31st March 2000, ie, the migration will begin on 1st January 2003. The release will be staggered over 9 months from 1st January 2003 to 1st October 2003. A 1% administrative fee is payable to SCANS. In this case, the fee will be based on the average of securities prices on the KLSE over the last five trading days of October 2002.

The Singapore Government had undertaken to ensure that SGX will abide by the agreement reached. I would deeply appreciate Your Excellency's confirmation, by reply to this letter, that the Malaysian Government likewise supports the agreement reached by the two exchanges, and

has undertaken to ensure that KLSE will abide by it".

I read from his third paragraph, "I have mentioned in my letter to Your Excellency dated 14th February 2000 that it is the stand of the Government of Malaysia that CLOB is a wholly private sector issue. As Your Excellency is aware, KLSE is a private sector organisation owned by its members. The agreements reached between KLSE and SGS confirmed this stand." But he went on, "As this is a comprehensive solution and the agreements are legally binding, I am confident KLSE will ensure that the obligations under the agreements are fully discharged. The Government of Malaysia looks forward to the smooth implementation of this comprehensive settlement." In other words, the KLSE-SGX agreement has the full support of both the Singapore and the Malaysian Governments.

    Some CLOB investors have written to the local press expressing disappointment with the solution reached and Mr Low has expressed some of their views just now. They feel that SGX and CDP should have insisted on CLOB investors' strict legal rights and taken a firm stand with the Malaysian authorities, particularly as Singapore was on sound legal ground. A few went further to suggest that by agreeing to the resolution, SGX has conceded that CLOB International was illegal and had merely been "talking tough" in the past months.

    SGX has not conceded any such thing. CLOB International was never illegal, and SGX's confidence in its legal position was based on informed legal advice. The Singapore authorities had also taken legal advice from leading experts on WTO matters. Our position was strong, both under Malaysian law and at the WTO. But legal action would have involved further delay, probably as long as several years, particularly in the case of our action in Malaysian courts. Meanwhile the prospect of delay and uncertainty would

Column: 1514

have caused many CLOB investors to feel compelled to accept private sector offers which were less favourable and had no legal assurance of being carried out by the KLSE. This included, in particular, Effective Capital's earlier staggered release proposal, which would have involved a 4 plus 18 months delay, starting in February this year.

    The fact that there were clear and unambiguous legal rights involving more than 172,000 investors of different nationalities, and that we were prepared to enforce these rights as a last resort, were clearly significant in helping SGX to reach a comprehensive and legally binding solution with the KLSE to serve the needs of CLOB investors. Although we did not eventually have to go to Court or go to the WTO, the legal position was important in establishing that we had a case and that therefore we were able to deal with KLSE and reach this agreement.

    In getting KLSE to finally negotiate and enter into a legally binding agreement spelling out specific terms of the staggered release of CLOB securities, SGX was acting in the best interests of investors. The terms of the schemes presented to CLOB investors are significantly improved from those previously offered. Each CLOB investor is in a different situation and has different interests, especially with regard to how long he is able to wait before being able to trade his shares. No resolution, whether through legal action or negotiation, could have met the needs of all investors equally. But the final negotiated settlement is a pragmatic one in the circumstances.

    The Securities Industries Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has, throughout this episode, provided independent representation of a substantial group of investors. It made clear its members' preferences, and took a resolute stand against earlier private sector offers that were to the disadvantage of investors.

    SIAS has on 26th February 2000 stated its view that the two schemes address the needs of most CLOB investors. It noted

Column: 1515

that its concerns had been addressed with the reduction of the ECSB proposal's staggered release period from 18 to 13 months, and with KLSE's legal undertaking to fully and unconditionally implement the migration.     The agreement commits KLSE, SCANS and their related companies to implement fully the two alternative schemes.
